description: Before US Cyber Command, the US military faced a difficult problem: How to prepare junior Soldiers, Marines, Sailors, and Airmen for the rigors and challenges of operational cyber roles despite many of them lacking basic computing and networking experience. The Joint Cyber Analysis Course (JCAC) emerged as a transformative solution. Breaking with military training conventions, JCAC produced a generation of skilled cyber operators and analysts building the formative workforce for US Cyber Command. 15 years later, JCAC remains a testament to innovation and resilience. Join me as we explore the secrets behind JCAC’s success and explore practical strategies applicable to anyone venturing into the world of cybersecurity. This talk offers insight into one of the most prevalent questions in our field: What do I need to know to get a job in Cybersecurity?
title: Building a Generation of Military Hackers: Behind the Scenes of the Joint Cyber Analysis Course

description:
Phone phreaking may be long dead, but the spirit lives on. In this talk, I'll present the short story of how, only a few years ago, a small group of friends explored, mapped, and manipulated our university's telephone system - and the hardware revival project it spawned that still continues today. What began as a freshman's prank call spiraled into a 500-line directory, a variety of number-mapping techniques of varying levels of cartoonish convolution, adventures in OSINT and history, and a dive into electronics RE and signals analysis.

We'll see how one or a few, with some dedication, can delve into any system: Even one that's as seemingly opaque as a beige brick on the wall.
title: Fear and Loathing at the Tone: A Savage Journey to the Heart of a Campus Telephone System

description:
Digital Forensics and Incident Response (DFIR) analysts and examiners have one of the most technically demanding roles across cyber. The data is often complex, detailed, and highly caveated. Regardless of how long you’ve been in the field, the hardest phase is often the end, when we are charged with reporting our findings, often to non-technical people. 
This session is for anyone looking to level up their storytelling ability. This session unveils how the art of storytelling, a cornerstone of D&D, can be a game-changer in the DFIR process. By adopting narrative techniques from the world of role-playing games, DFIR professionals can enhance their ability to communicate complex information in a compelling way. Whether you are testifying in court, presenting findings to a client, or getting up on stage to talk through a particularly interesting case, our storytelling ability will be how people remember our work. Join us to learn how to gain Advantage on your next forensic analysis and turn it into a captivating tale that informs, engages, and resonates.
Embark on a quest to master DFIR storytelling, drawing inspiration from D&D to tackle various aspects of DFIR. This session aims to explain the DFIR process and build capacity for practitioners of any experience level. Topics will include:
•	Team Building
•	Preparation and Skill Building
•	Evidence Collection
•	Data Analysis and Interpretation
•	Reporting and Documentation
•	Incident Response and Management
•	Communication and Collaboration
•	Ethical Considerations
This session will not only demystify the DFIR process but also empower attendees to tell their own cybersecurity stories with confidence and clarity. By the end, participants will have a new set of tools to bring their DFIR narratives to life.

description: Join Sr. Director Jared Greenhill and Director Clint Patterson from Unit 42 as they explore a multifaceted BlackCat ransomware attack on a small government. They'll share insights into how essential services from email to airport operations were disrupted and the complex journey toward recovery amidst extensive system encryption. This session will also reveal the surprising origin of the attack, which highlights the unexpected ways an attack surface can grow, and novel tools and techniques employed by the threat actors.
title: When BlackCat Pounces: A Ransomware Tale from Personal Device to Governmental Impact

description: This talk will focus on new research into the concept of Default Application Hijacking, a persistent technique where attackers can hijack which applications open specific file types by default on MacOS. Default Application Hijacking can be abused to coerce privileges from unsuspecting users, gain initial access to targets, or install stealthy persistence. It can also be used to break basic Mac functionality in such a way that they become unusable until fixed. This is a bug which still remains unpatched on MacOS, at least up to Sonoma 14.5 (this affects both ARM and Intel versions)
title: Default Application Hijacking, a Persistent MacOS Problem

description: More often than not, the immediate response for cyber actions is against the topical infrastructure from adversaries. These response actions of blocking an IP, sinkholing a domain, and signatureing a malware hash most often have short-term impacts that sometimes the adversary has even planned for. As the adversaries grow in complexity and resiliency the response tactics and actions from Defenders and Operators must adjust as well. This presentation will outline some historical examples (past hacks) of ways to actively disrupt adversary operations in unconventional ways. These tactics are indirect but can pose devastating losses to adversary operations in the cyber environment. Similar to taking out the ball bearing factory to disable tanks, the tradecraft discussed here will stimulate and provide examples of alternative tactics to use against our toughest cyber adversaries.

description:
Join us for an engaging one-hour career focused panel discussion featuring Jamie, Andy, and John — seasoned cybersecurity veterans with over 60 years of combined experience across diverse roles within the cybersecurity industry. 

This panel promises honest, no-nonsense answers to your burning questions about cybersecurity careers.

Jamie, Andy, and John bring a wealth of expertise from their respective journeys in cybersecurity—from hands-on technical roles to strategic leadership positions. 

They will delve into the realities of working in this dynamic field, offering invaluable insights and practical advice for aspiring professionals and seasoned practitioners alike.

Throughout the session, the panelists will address a wide range of topics, including:
•	Navigating career paths in cybersecurity
•	Essential skills and certifications
•	Challenges and opportunities in the field
•	Tips for career advancement and professional development

Bring your questions and get ready for an unfiltered discussion that cuts through the noise to provide clear, actionable guidance.

Whether you're exploring a career in cybersecurity or seeking to elevate your existing role, this panel promises to equip you with the insights needed to thrive in this critical and ever-evolving industry.

Don't miss out on this opportunity to hear from Jamie, Andy, and John—where straight talk meets cybersecurity expertise.

description: In this talk, we'll explore the dynamic partnership between a data scientist and a threat hunter as they join forces to elevate their company's machine learning (ML) powered detection and response capabilities. By blending threat intelligence with advanced ML techniques, they were able to create capabilities to  uncover unknown threats across various data sources. Attendees will gain an understanding on how to bring ML into their detection strategy, practical applications of machine learning for threat detection,  and understanding how to layer it with attacker operations and threat intelligence to enhance detection strategies, and see real-world examples of these concepts in action.

description: In our increasingly digital world, detecting malicious activities via DNS analysis has become crucial for cybersecurity. This presentation briefly discusses DNS basics, domain registration norms, and dives into several advanced detection techniques to enhance security measures and identify data exfiltration, C2 communications, and other malicious activities.
title: What’s in a Name – Hiding in Plain Sight

description: While most people think of Security Onion as a network security monitoring solution, which it is, it's often overlooked that it is also a powerful platform for log ingestion and analysis. This talk will cover the capabilities of the platform to ingest logs from a variety of sources, how those logs are normalized and stored, the tools that are available for hunting through them for malicious or suspicious activity, and how we can perform basic detection engineering to alert on known problematic events.

description: This presentation provides a concise overview of the teaching strategies employed in academic and government institutions to educate individuals on information warfare. Academic institutions integrate these disciplines into their curricula, while government institutions, and academies, also emphasize specialized training programs. The multidisciplinary nature of information warfare actively encompasses cybersecurity, psychological operations, Operations Security, electronic warfare, deception techniques, and associated intelligence support. Curriculum integration involves adapting existing programs to address emerging information warfare threats. Specialized training initiatives, such as workshops and simulations, enhance preparedness and response capabilities in government institutions.  This presentation emphasizes the role of academic and government institutions in equipping individuals with the knowledge and skills required to navigate the complexities of information warfare. To highlight the foundational differences in approach, we investigate similarities and differences in policy and lexicons unique to distinct cultures. By adopting interdisciplinary approaches, adapting curricula, providing specialized training, and considering cultural nuances, these institutions contribute to developing competent professionals capable of safeguarding national security in the digital age.

description:
Despite significant advancements in information security over the past two decades, vulnerability management has remained a persistent challenge. Traditional methods often result in a frantic, inefficient race to address critical vulnerabilities, leading to large-scale incidents and breaches even in well-funded organizations. The emergence of Generative AI presents an opportunity to revolutionize this process and introduce an open-source tool.

The "Cyber WatchDog tool" leverages a privately hosted AI system using retrieval-augmented generation, prompt engineering, open-source large language models, and machine learning to provide rapid, actionable insights from internal and external data sources. By integrating data from internal Configuration Management Databases (CMDBs) and external sources, Cyber WatchDog validates, assesses, and enriches vulnerability data in real-time. This approach enables organizations to efficiently identify and respond to zero-days and known exploitable vulnerabilities.

This talk will demonstrate a practical use case involving the daily monitoring of the CISA Known Exploitable Vulnerabilities (KEV) feed. Cyber WatchDog verifies the applicability of new vulnerabilities to your organization's environment and enriches this data with inputs from Shodan, Pastebin, Telegram and cybercrime forums. This process allows security teams to prioritize limited resources on incident response, while providing leadership with accurate, timely answers, metrics and insights on vulnerabilities. 

This session will demonstrate how we built a home-grown AI Cyber WatchDog tool to demonstrate the capabilities of private AI.  The latest release of this open source tool will be publicly released at BSIDES NoVA for anyone that wants to use it!


Please note that the open source project is available here:
https://github.com/TheShadoru/AI-Cyber-Watchdog

Two of our contributors will also be joining me for the talk(if we are selected)
Joe Carroll
https://www.linkedin.com/in/joseph-c-562529204/
Ujval Bucha
https://www.linkedin.com/in/ujvalbucha/

description:
Web Application Firewalls (WAFs) and input validation are common measures to prevent malicious responses from being generated in web applications and APIs. However, the interaction between various systems such as the application server and SQL databases can sometimes be exploited to bypass these restrictions.

This presentation will discuss and define request mutation, a technique that involves sending safe requests that are later changed into unsafe requests after being validated. By exploiting this method of encoded injection, attackers can bypass safety measures in vulnerable systems in order to successfully exploit vulnerabilities that are typically protected by WAFs, such as cross-site scripting (XSS). Not only will the presentation discuss this technique on a theoretical level, but it will also walk through a real-world example that works with the help of an up-to-date version of Microsoft SQL Server to bypass WAF protections and exploit an XSS vulnerability. Pentesters will be able to level up their skills, seeing a new method of defeating defenses through canonicalization that arise through this technique. Additionally, this presentation will help developers understand the importance of defense-in-depth measures such as encoding database output.
title: Request Mutation and Why WAFs Can't Save You

description: In Hunting Your First C2, attendees who are beginning their cyber journeys will learn how to tap open source intelligence tools including Shodan, Greynoise, Censys, BinaryEdge, VirusTotal, and others to track down fresh malware C2 indicators and servers. Once unique and interesting indicators are found, attendees will learn how to potentially pivot on this information and translate it into actionable threat hunting logic to defend an organization.

description:
Why is this an important topic now?
	SLIDE 1
		Fundamentally different than the type of defenses and mental models most organizations have in place today
		Push vs. pull style attack – “Poison the well” and wait for organizations to “compromise themselves”
		Heavy focus on enterprise security controls (EDR, SIEM/SOAR, email security, network security, etc.)
		Multiple perspectives – consumer vs. producer (most organizations are likely both and different controls apply to each perspective)
	SLIDE 2 
		Highly attractive target rich environment for adversaries
			Growing attack vector (lots of research and tooling)
			Economies of scale for malicious actors
			Becoming the path of least resistance (optimistically)
	SLIDE 3
	Business/Compliance requirements are more commonly being imposed
	Tooling is improving in this space
	
Defining the problem space
	SLIDE 4
		Industry definitions – this is part of the problem, no agreed upon scope or it's discussed so broadly that it loses tangible meaning
		Equally as important to not define the space too narrowly – more than just SBOMs and SCA tools
	SLIDE 5
		Practical definition
			Source
			Build
			Package & Deploy
	SLIDE 6
		SLSA threat model – link to OpenSSF reference threat model
		
Source
	SLIDE 7
		Reference Threat model - https://boostsecurity.io/blog/slsa-dip-at-the-source-of-the-problem 
	SLIDE 8
		Example – XZ backdoor
		
Build
	SLIDE 9
		Reference Threat model - https://boostsecurity.io/blog/slsa-dip-its-build-time 
	SLIDE 10
		Example – Bazel project compromise - https://cycode.com/blog/cycode-discovers-a-supply-chain-vulnerability-in-bazel/ 

Package & Deploy
	SLIDE 11
		Example – CodeCov breach
		
Where to start as a defender?
	SLIDE 12
		Don’t reinvent the wheel – CI/CD infrastructure is not much different than other assets, it can be instrumented and hardened, and logging/alerting is extremely important (eBPF on the runners to enforce network policy and audit other events)
	SLIDE 13
		Leverage OSS tools (legitify, poutine, etc.) & threat modeling to understand your attack surface, assess that attack surface, and identify any gaping security flaws that need fixed ASAP
	SLIDE 14
		Start small and phase it in – pick a specific initiative or control that will have an outsized impact on improving security posture (branch protection, dependency pinning, etc.)
		Adopt a framework to better align organizational outcomes – highly recommend P-SSCRM
	SLIDE 15
		Add automations (auto create PRs for dependencies, pin dependencies, etc.), policy controls (AllStar, controls within SCM itself, frizbee/Minder), and guardrails/developer guidance (OpenSSF scorecards, gitsign/cosign, trusted base images, i.e. good in, good out) as the program matures

description: Cybersecurity is a rapidly growing field that demands a diverse set of skills and a commitment to lifelong learning. As the job market evolves, workforce gaps continue to emerge, offering opportunities for qualified professionals.  While technical skills are essential for many roles, future cybersecurity professionals will also benefit from cross-functional abilities that can be developed across various positions. This session will explore the in-demand skills that, alongside strong technical fundamentals, are crucial for preparing for a successful career in cybersecurity.  This session will provide guidance on potential cyber career pathways, the durable skills in demand for today's workforce, and resources for charting your course that are applicable whether you are new to the field, pivoting to cyber, or exploring options for career growth,
title: Feed Your Cybercuriosity: Leveraging Diverse Skillsets for Success!

description:
At BSides NoVA 2022, we presented research on vulnerabilities in state-level political party websites across the US. This year, we're back to share the evolution of that work into a non-partisan nationwide election cybersecurity initiative that’s racing to beat the clock on securing political parties on both sides of the aisle ahead of the 2024 Election. Along the way, we’ll explore what happens when you try to email the DNC CISO about all of his websites being vulnerable, how the Texas Republicans keep getting hacked, and why your local party office should probably update their passwords. 

We'll dive into the technologies that power this initiative, including an in-depth look at the cloud-based web monitoring and breach detection system that's discovered vulnerabilities in over 98% of political party websites. We'll demonstrate how the platform has expanded to secure not just state-level parties but also local and county-level organizations, highlighting the impact this work is having on election cybersecurity efforts nationwide. In addition to the technical aspects, we'll share some of the challenges and successes of building a cybersecurity startup armed with little more than a passion project, lots of coffee, and the power of a good laptop sticker.

We're looking forward to sharing the intersection of innovative technology, cybersecurity entrepreneurship, and the critical mission of election security.

description: This session will introduce a cyber deception practitioner's conceptual framework for designing and operationalizing corporate cyber deception sock puppets. This is a concentrated design for operational application of sock puppets, in support of a plausible technical and real or imagined storyline.  This framework can also be used for assessing the credibility of sock puppets.  This practitioner's comprehensive framework advances the limited sock puppet toolkits or modeling guides out there, offering one of the only behaviorally concentrated frameworks for building authentic sock puppets for operational use and for assessing the credibility of online sock puppets or genuine accounts.  This conceptual framework is based on six relational brackets, derived from transdisciplinary behavioral foundations and experiential application in government and industry cyber deception.  I will introduce and familiarize the audience with these six relational brackets, and then demonstrate application of this framework by storyboarding the creation of a sock puppet for operational use in a theoretical storyline and operational scenario.  The sock puppet will be a retro gamer.  Within a cyber deception context, this sock puppet framework can be used for offensive or defensive purposes or for passive or active sock puppet use.

description:
In the realm of cybersecurity, the battle against phishing attacks remains a perpetual challenge. While email providers offer spam filters and enterprises invest in sophisticated anti-phishing solutions, there's a noticeable gap in accessibility for the average internet user. This session delves into the journey of building an anti-phishing tool tailored for regular people, exploring the challenges encountered and the valuable lessons learned along the way.

At the outset of 2023, the absence of a free, user-friendly anti-phishing tool for everyday individuals sparked a realization: Why not build one? Thus began the journey of crafting an anti-phishing plugin designed to empower users worldwide. However, the path to success was far from straightforward. Initial attempts resulted in setbacks, with the first iteration falling short of expectations.

Through perseverance and a commitment to improvement, the anti-phishing plugin evolved, eventually making the Google Workspace Top Rated page. Yet, the journey was marked by numerous trials and tribulations, each offering valuable insights into the complexities of email analysis and phishing detection.

Throughout the session, I'll share firsthand accounts of the mistakes made and the invaluable lessons gleaned. From the intricacies of email headers to the subtleties of sender authentication protocols, we'll dissect the technical nuances that underpin effective phishing detection.

description:
Can MySQL server attack YOU? Can a black hat hacker execute a code on your laptop if you will simply login to a hacked MySQL database server? Is it even possible?

Our research journey began by revisiting a security issue dating back to 2019, an issue that Oracle MySQL never unequivocally acknowledged. While the closest Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs) references were CVE-2020-2570, CVE-2020-2574, and CVE-2020-2575, our team discovered that unfixed old client libraries, such as MySQL C/C++ connectors and MySQL ODBC drivers, as well as command line and GUI tools like MySQL CLI and MySQL Workbench, inadvertently permit attackers to execute arbitrary code on the client machine.

But the story doesn't end there. We uncovered another layer of vulnerability: the ability to use a multibyte character set to circumvent a security patch in the MySQL server code. This revelation introduces a brand new zero-day vulnerability in the MySQL server, thereby enabling an attack vector against MySQL client libraries, command line interfaces, and graphical user interface tools. We have submitted this finding to Oracle MySQL, which was fixed in the latest MySQL version. The new CVE-2023-21980 was created and acknowledged in Oracle Critical Patch Update Advisory - April 2023.

Our presentation will unveil a novel attack vector, one where MySQL database clients, including applications using the C API, become the unsuspecting targets of an elaborate attack chain. Our team will demonstrate a complete attack scenario discovered against MySQL client applications, leading to remote code execution. Furthermore, we will illustrate the use of multibyte character set encoding to exploit non-multi-byte-safe or improperly written code.
title: MySQL server attacks YOU! (How we found CVE-2023-21980 in MySQL)

description: No one questions that ransomware is a major problem, but without initial access brokers there would be less ransomware, yet initial access does not get the attention it deserves. This talk will look at the most common methods of initial access, including phishing, credential stuffing/reuse, exploitation, social engineering and third party and discuss ways to defend against these types of attacks. More importantly, like Bruce Lee when he is staving off 7 attackers at once, it will look at how you defend against these disparate attacks simultaneously.
title: Access Brokers of Fury: Lessons We Can Learn from Bruce Lee to Better Defend Against Initial Access

description:
Permaculture is a systems-oriented approach toward ethical, sustainable, and resilient food production. At its core, it represents a cultural shift from being dependent consumers toward becoming responsible producers. The principles and practices of permaculture present a novel way of considering and addressing software security challenges.

With this talk, attendees will walk away with a new (non-militaristic) way of framing software security challenges that centers resilience and empathy. Tactically, attendees will also be given specific examples of how this framing can be used in the capacity of product security work to drive toward better outcomes.
title: Leveraging permaculture principles to improve software security

description:
Abstract:
Red Team campaigns simulate real adversaries and provide real value to the organization by exposing vulnerable infrastructure and processes that need to be improved. The challenge is that as organizations scale in size, time between campaign retesting increases. This can lead to gaps in ensuring coverage and finding emerging issues. Automation and simulation of adversarial attacks can be created to address the scale problem. Collecting libraries of Tactics, Techniques and Procedures (TTPs) and testing them via adversarial emulation software. Unfortunately, automation lacks feedback and cannot analyze the data in real time with each test.

To address this problem, we introduce RAMPART (Repeated And Measured Post Access Red Teaming). RAMPART campaigns are very quick campaigns (1- 5 days) meant to bridge the gap between the automation of Red Team simulations and full blown Red Team campaigns. The speed of these campaigns comes from pre-built playbooks backed by Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) research. This approach enables a level of freedom to make decisions based on the data the red team analyst sees from their tooling and allows testing further in the attack chain to test detections that could be missed otherwise.

Description of Slides:
RAMPART embraces a true purple team approach, working very closely with the Security Operations Center (SOC). In this talk, we will cover what happens in a typical Red Team engagement, how the Red Team will execute their campaign, how they write up their findings and provide that to the SOC for review. In contrast we will discuss how RAMPART, adds in the element of scorecarding. This scorecard clearly outlines all of the steps taken during a RAMPART campaign giving the SOC analyst the ability to quickly and easily review and determine whether there is coverage for that specific TTP. Next, time is given to the SOC and sister teams to remediate issues and add additional logging and detections. Finally, the RAMPART team will retest the environment to ensure coverage.

We will also discuss challenges as working with the SOC in this way does add friction. RAMPART is asking the SOC to monitor for risks that they may or may not already be monitoring for. Some items may require extensive engineering to be created. Such as working with a non-networked entity to provide additional logging to the SOC. Either side may not have the cycles to dedicate to such an effort.

Finally we will discuss how RAMPART campaigns should not be a complete replacement for Red Team campaigns. It is a great supplement to any security program. Giving security operations teams the ability to quickly and easily test numerous environments to ensure adequate coverage for detection engineering.

description:
Join us for an engaging panel discussion featuring a threat intelligence platform CEO, a top executive recruiter, and XYZ/so-and-so where we explore the intricacies of recruitment and career transitions in the tech industry. Our panel will provide valuable insights from industry leaders and recruitment experts and contrast the differences between Europe and the US. 

Hacking the Recruitment Process: Strategies for standing out in the job market. 

Recruiter Visibility: Getting the attention of executive recruiters and having them work for you.   

EU vs. US Career Dynamics: A comparative look at recruitment practices, opportunities, and challenges across the Atlantic. 

Transitioning In and Out of Government Roles: Insights on moving between public service and private sector leadership. 

Breaking into Senior Roles: Tips and strategies for securing top positions in tech, in Europe and the US.  

The session will feature at least one personal story from our speakers, sharing how they overcame obstacles, approached personal growth, and what they might do differently in hindsight. 

AMA last 10 minutes

description: What would someone know about you if they had all of the information saved in your browser? More importantly, what would you know about the world if you had 60 million random samples of all of the information saved in the browsers of others? Join Nick Ascoli on a deep dive into the fascinating world of stealer logs. Nick has spent more than 6 months examining the world's most comprehensive stealer log data set to understand... well, everything. What can you learn from the credentials on a cyber criminals computer? Or of a government official from an adversarial nation? Nick will examine the trends, implications, markets, and defenses around one of the most interesting data sets for intelligence to be built in the past decade, while maintaining a healthy sense of humor and more than a little fear of Polonium poisoning.

description:
Zero-day web server exploits are notoriously difficult to detect, and we’ll always be able to find a way around exploit detection solutions whether they are based on traditional signatures, or AI or the latest buzzword. However, my research has made use of an opportunity, namely that RCE exploits against a web server on one OS have never coexisted with RCE exploits against a different web server on a separate OS, as supported by Project Zero data. So what if we were able to poll the results of 2 or more web servers to see if anything’s different with one of the responses before returning a final response?

I will show what has been done to split a request to a web server, send it to separate web servers that are highly unlikely to contain the same vulnerability, and generate a response based on the responses from the two web servers.  Even if one of the web servers was exploited and sent back sensitive data, this will be detected and the result is only that the attacker will see an error page.
title: Por Que No Los Dos? Creating a Secure Web Server from Multiple Vulnerable Web Servers

description: Ben Coon and Bobby Preston will dive into Telegram’s growing role in credential phishing (and cybercrime), and share analysis from one year’s worth of threat actor logs, conversations and files. Attendees will gain a clear understanding of the platform’s nuances, as well as dispelling common misconceptions around visibility and access. Participants will be encouraged to capitalize on threat actors' use of Telegram as a strategic advantage to drive disruption and intervene more effectively.

description:
Have you ever presented to an audience who wasn't paying attention? Sent a DM that went unanswered?

As security professionals, we have important things to say, but we're not always heard.

I want to help your ideas be heard, understood, and acted on based on my lessons learned serving time-sensitive clients and working in startups and a 40,000+ person enterprise.

Your strategy: Make it easy for your audience to understand your ideas and act on it.

In this talk, you'll learn tactical tips on how to do that, including:
- Tailoring your message to your audience based on their interests
- Communicating clearly, concisely, and directly
- Being solution- and action-oriented in your communications
- Getting feedback on your communications

Let's turn you into a hacker of hearts and minds.

description:
Explore the mind of Ivan Kondratev, also known as Bassterlord, the infamous hacker indicted by the United States Department of Justice (DoJ). Earlier this year, Ivan was charged with orchestrating some of the world's most damaging ransomware attacks. Following the indictment, Bassterlord claimed he was not Ivan and asserted that he had misled both researchers and law enforcement, causing them to accuse an innocent person of his crimes.
Over the past few years, Azim Khodjibaev and Jon DiMaggio have conducted in-depth research into the human aspect of ransomware, getting to know Bassterlord personally. Jon and Azim will share their insights from interactions with the hacker and his criminal associates, detailing significant crimes Bassterlord committed. Despite Bassterlord's claim that he is not Ivan, those who know him well say otherwise.
Jon and Azim will also discuss information previously detailed in the Ransomware Diaries, which narrated Bassterlord's origin story, along with insights and screenshots that Azim obtained from Bassterlord. These screenshots include Bassterlord’s Lockbit panel, forum logins, and victim information. Interestingly, many aspects of this story overlap with newly identified events from Ivan's life, supporting the DoJ's attribution. For example, Bassterlord mentioned to Jon and Azim that he had bad vision. Coincidentally, Ivan Kondratiev also wears prescription glasses.
Finally, they will share details about their relationship with Bassterlord, a mix of good and bad, which offers a rare insight into the mind of an infamous cybercriminal.

Introduction (5 minutes)
Welcome and Introduction
Brief introduction of the presenters: Azim Khodjibaev and Jon DiMaggio
Overview of the session’s agenda
Background on Ivan Kondratev (Bassterlord)
Brief biography

Introduction to his alias, Bassterlord
Section 1: The Indictment and Denial (10 minutes)
Details of the Indictment
Charges brought by the United States Department of Justice
Overview of the ransomware attacks attributed to Ivan
Bassterlord’s Denial
Bassterlord’s claim of not being Ivan
Alleged misleading of researchers and law enforcement

Section 2: Personal Interactions and Research Findings (10 minutes)
Research Journey
Azim and Jon’s in-depth research process
Getting to know Bassterlord personally
Insights from Interactions
Key learnings from conversations with Bassterlord
Interaction with Bassterlord’s criminal associates

Section 3: Significant Crimes Committed by Bassterlord (10 minutes)
Detailed Account of Major Ransomware Attacks
Description of significant crimes
Impact and consequences of these attacks
Refutation of Bassterlord’s Claim
Evidence from close associates and interactions
Contradictions in Bassterlord’s narrative

Section 4: The Ransomware Diaries (10 minutes)
Overview of the Ransomware Diaries
Bassterlord’s origin story
Insights gathered by Jon and Azim from Bassterlord
Screenshots and Evidence
Presentation of screenshots: Lockbit panel, forum logins, victim information
Correlation with newly identified events from Ivan’s life

Conclusion and Q&A (5 minutes)
Summarizing Key Points
Recap of Ivan Kondratev’s indictment, Bassterlord’s denial, and research findings
Key takeaways from the Ransomware Diaries

Question and Answer Session
Open floor for questions from the audience
Provide detailed answers and additional insights

Closing (2 minutes)
Final Thoughts
Implications for future research and law enforcement
Contact information for further queries
Thank You
Thank the audience for their time and participation

Charges brought by the United States Department of Justice
Overview of the ransomware attacks attributed to Ivan
Bassterlord’s Denial
Bassterlord’s claim of not being Ivan
Alleged misleading of researchers and law enforcement

Section 2: Personal Interactions and Research Findings (10 minutes)
Research Journey
Azim and Jon’s in-depth research process
Getting to know Bassterlord personally
Insights from Interactions
Key learnings from conversations with Bassterlord
Interaction with Bassterlord’s criminal associates

Section 3: Significant Crimes Committed by Bassterlord (10 minutes)
Detailed Account of Major Ransomware Attacks
Description of significant crimes
Impact and consequences of these attacks
Refutation of Bassterlord’s Claim
Evidence from close associates and interactions
Contradictions in Bassterlord’s narrative

Section 4: The Ransomware Diaries (10 minutes)
Overview of the Ransomware Diaries
Bassterlord’s origin story
Insights gathered by Jon and Azim from Bassterlord
Screenshots and Evidence
Presentation of screenshots: Lockbit panel, forum logins, victim information
Correlation with newly identified events from Ivan’s life

Conclusion and Q&A (5 minutes)
Summarizing Key Points
Recap of Ivan Kondratev’s indictment, Bassterlord’s denial, and research findings
Key takeaways from the Ransomware Diaries

Question and Answer Session
Open floor for questions from the audience
Provide detailed answers and additional insights

Closing (2 minutes)
Final Thoughts
Implications for future research and law enforcement
Contact information for further queries
Thank You
Thank the audience for their time and participation

description:
In the 1800s, lamplighters were employed to light gas streetlights that had replaced the previous generation of candles and oil lamps. However, with the advent of incandescent lighting and the automation provided by electricity, lamplighters became largely obsolete. 

For decades, we’ve relied on vulnerability scanners to assess our assets and generate reports containing IP addresses and their associated CVEs. CVEs add value but only represent a subset of your risk exposure. They completely miss critical variables such as the presence and state of endpoint IT management and security controls, making them largely obsolete when relied upon in a vacuum. 

This reliance on CVE data leads to a distorted view of an asset's risk level, making it difficult to prioritize remediation efforts accurately. This also negatively impacts overall organizational risk, while the sheer volume of CVE data wastes time, money, and resources. 

Does it matter how many CVEs you detect if the device has no controls to remediate them? A modern approach to vulnerability management must transcend the realm of CVEs and encompass exposures related to environmental vulnerabilities. These include gaps like missing endpoint controls, outdated or non-communicative controls, and misconfigurations. 

When it comes to CVEs, in many cases, CVE data can be pulled directly from IT management and security controls that you already have installed on your endpoints. This negates or greatly reduces the value derived from a traditional vulnerability scanner, which, by its nature, can also be risky to run and onerous to operationalize as part of an integrated vulnerability management strategy. Regardless of where the operating system and application CVEs are derived, they must be correlated with environmental vulnerabilities. 

After correlating CVEs and environmental variables, your vulnerability management strategy can be taken to the next level. Risk prioritization can include identity data and business context enrichment by linking assets with regulatory mandates, critical systems, supply chains, geographic regions, business units, etc. 

With this level of accuracy in risk prioritization, automated ticketing and response integration capabilities can be efficiently and effectively leveraged with the understanding of which risks may be mitigated or are already being mitigated by existing IT management and security controls. Finally, your vulnerability management strategy can be more formally operationalized with real-time remediation validation to ensure that what was stated as being fixed was actually fixed and stays fixed, as well as metrics to measure the effectiveness of your remediation efforts.

description:
GreyNoise: Every Packet Has a Story

Since 2018, GreyNoise has been operating a network of thousands of sensors spanning hundreds of data centers and networks across dozens of countries. Over the years, we've detected millions of compromised devices, bared witness to hundreds of mass Nday exploitation campaigns, and tracked hundreds of benign scanning operations. We've watched network traffic start, stop, and change due to kinetic wars, and we've built a platform trusted by thousands of organizations across the world. Operating a system of this scale brings lots of cool challenges, opportunities, and unexplainable phenomena. In this talk I'll give the origin story of GreyNoise for the first time, discuss highlights and lowlights, regale weird stories, and share the exciting path forward.

description:
AI is all around us and rapidly advancing in Cyber and other domains.
Come to this hands on workshop led by AI expert Tom Bendien and his AI Coaches to broaden your understanding of the GenAI ecosystem and gain hands-on skills.
The workshop is beginner friendly while providing the opportunity for more advanced practitioners to learn new skills.

Prerequisites:
All training will be web based with an email and 2FA required for login.


Optional for hands on workshop requiring software installation and configuration:
A BYO Windows, Linux or Mac computer is required for the hands on sessions requiring the installation of open source software.


Attendees can work together in small groups to see the open source AI software in action if they do not wish to run the hands on part of the sessions themselves.
A limited number of training laptops will be provided for group activities.


A list of pre requisite software that must be installed on BYO computers before the workshop is shown below.
WiFi Internet access will be limited, so the more prerequisite software you can install, the faster you will be able to get to work!


Follow the lab shown here to prepare your BYO computer for the workshop:
https://gtcyberlabs.org/f/local-ai-installation-quickstart


Workshop formats/options:
1. All online using the GT Cyber Labs web based Bionic GPT AI platform 100% web based.
No pre requisites other than registration and 2FA setup.


2. Full local AI install workshop requires BYO computer or use the provided laptops in small groups.
(note that we will not be able to provide open source software installation troubleshooting support for BYO computers).

Get your tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bsidesnova-2024-8-bit-games-sept-6-7-arlington-va-tickets-971314707437

description:
Welcome to Security AI! The goal of this course is to inform on how artificial intelligence is becoming one of the major tools in our security arsenal. The problem is that, unless mom you have a specific type of degree, you are at the mercy of product vendors,collaborators, ChatGPT, or search engines to understand these concepts. This course demystifies artificial intelligence and its relationships.

This is an interactive course, with the goal of teaching security professionals how to implement AI in order to obtain valuable insights. This course will encompass various topics including: machine learning (ML), natural language processing (NLP), and large-language models (LLMs). The combination of AI and security allows the security community to move our assumptions, opinions and beliefs into knowledge.

No previous experience is necessary. Background understanding programming is very helpful, specifically Python.

Module 	Title
00 	Intro to Security Plus Data Science
01 	Intro to Jupyter Notebook
02 	Intro to Python and Libraries
03 	What is Data?
04 	What is Data Visualization?
05 	Data Science Process
06 	Network Analysis
07 	Time-Series Analysis
08 	Security Plus Data Science Competition 1
09 	Intro to Machine Learning
10 	Anomaly Detection with Unsupervised Learning
11 	Phishing Website Detection
12 	Network Intrusion Detection
13 	Fraud Detection
14 	Security Plus Data Science Competition 2
15 	Spam Detection
16 	Generative Adversial Malware
17 	Large Language Models

title: Lunch

description:
This workshop will present an introduction to the basic concepts of threat analysis, leveraging open-source tools, and processing threat intelligence reports in support of computer network defense and incident response.  This is a workshop for blue teamers (current and future!) that are interested in threat analysis. It will include discussing publicly available tools along with covering processes that are actionable today without additional training or paid accounts. 
We will start the workshop in an academic segment to build a baseline of key terms and the distinction between Cyber Intelligence and Cyber Threat Analysis.  Once we have a common foundation, we will move into a hands-on portion exploring open-source reports to enrich and pivot within our dataset. I will demonstrate the process that I use to read through the content of a threat report, process the IOCs and TTPs, and correlate the activity to previous reporting. This section of the workshop will work through Symantec’s Waterbug reporting along with ESET’s Turla reporting, as examples of the same activity being reported under different names and from different perspectives. Attendees will conduct passive lookups (e.g. VirusTotal, ThreatMiner, and PassiveTotal) on the IOCs included in the report.  In the final portion of the class, we will discuss bringing our analysis back together into an intelligence product. We will discuss the best methods for clustering threat activity, categorizing capabilities, and visualizing threat activity.  

Requirements- the class will require access to the internet. Students will require a laptop where they can download PDF and Excel files.  We will not require downloading and installing software.  Students should have a burner email account for free-tool registration (somewhere for sales emails to go to that won’t annoy them) as we will register for a few free accounts. 

Get your tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bsidesnova-2024-8-bit-games-sept-6-7-arlington-va-tickets-971314707437

description:
Capture the Flag (CTF) competitions offer a great way to acquire new technical skills. If you have never participated in a CTF event before, it can feel intimidating to try. This workshop will walk you through the different types of cybersecurity competitions and go in-depth on jeopardy-style CTFs. You will learn what skills are needed to participate, how to approach the challenges, and what are some of the common tools you may want to be familiar with. We will go over an example CTF as a group, and you will have a chance to work through several example CTF challenges at your own pace with unlimited hints and guidance from our volunteers. We hope that you walk away not only with some new security skills but also the confidence to participate in a CTF on your own.

Get your tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bsidesnova-2024-8-bit-games-sept-6-7-arlington-va-tickets-971314707437

description:
All hackers need tools. In this workshop, students will be given devices to program and customize. We will use freely available software to configure our devices to act as our hacker gadgets.

Get your tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bsidesnova-2024-8-bit-games-sept-6-7-arlington-va-tickets-971314707437
		 
Throughout this workshop we will build the following
	 
	- A malicious USB device used to inject scripts to an unlocked computer
	 
	- A bootable Kali Linux USB device, to load Kali onto a computer without changing the host operating system
	 
	- An ESP32 Wi-Fi hacking device to capture wireless handshakes so that passwords can be cracked
	 
We will discuss the security implications of each of these devices, how they can be used maliciously and how you can mitigate against the attacks.  To do this we will discuss the tech behind the attacks so we can understand what is happening.  We will use the tools, we will hack and we will learn.
		 
All devices will be provided for the students to build and keep.  All presentation and lab documentation will be provided so you can exercise with these tools at home.  
	 
This is a beginner level class and no previous programming experience is required.  All labs will have instructions to follow step by step.

description:
Now in its seventh iteration since the initial launch, the Cloud Forensics Workshop has been a regular feature at multiple security conferences where students new to the industry or individuals interested in cross-training learn core concepts about digital forensics in the Cloud.  The latest version of this training session - dubbed the "AI Edition" - now focuses on how artificial intelligence and automation can assist with a digital forensic investigation; including securing a compromised account, creating the necessary artifacts for forensic analysis; log indexing, correlation, and analysis to help identify suspicious activity or other unusual behaviors to generate a timeline of events.  The all-day workshop will feature plenty of group discussions on recent advancements in forensic automation, how the Cloud has evolved from large-scale virtual servers to smaller scalable containers, how IoT devices have extended the logical boundaries of the Cloud, and key similarities and differences between the three major Cloud Service Providers.  There will also be hands-on labs where students can learn more about automating tasks, mirroring and capturing packet data, and open-source tools and techniques that are commonly used in the field.  Students will be given the opportunity to download sample data from a Cloud account prior to the start of the class to help better understand how to leverage these tools and techniques.

Get your tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bsidesnova-2024-8-bit-games-sept-6-7-arlington-va-tickets-971314707437
